one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle‑aged woman with advanced AIDS off HAART and ESRD on hemodialysis presented from dialysis with pain, swelling, and purulent drainage around a right femoral tunneled dialysis catheter, along with post‑dialysis hypotension. She was briefly hypotensive in the ED but responded to approximately 3 liters of IV fluids and remained hemodynamically stable thereafter. Workup showed clear lungs and normal heart size on chest X‑ray, mild stress‑type troponin elevation without ischemic EKG changes, and chronic macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia consistent with HIV‑related pancytopenia and CKD. The infected right femoral catheter was removed, blood cultures remained negative, and she received an empiric 7‑day course of vancomycin (with early cefepime discontinued) while a new left femoral tunneled dialysis catheter was placed under IR guidance after an initial failed attempt. Difficult catheter advancement raised concern for IVC thrombus, prompting a short heparin infusion, but CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast showed a patent IVC without thrombus, innumerable bilateral renal cysts, and small splenic hemangiomas, so anticoagulation was stopped. She continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis via the new catheter with improved BUN/creatinine and potassium control, completed a short course of nystatin for presumed oral candidiasis, and remained off HAART while continuing PCP and MAC prophylaxis. Her right thigh infection site healed without abscess or bacteremia, her blood pressure stabilized at her low baseline, and she was discharged home with visiting nurse services, a functioning left femoral dialysis catheter, and follow‑up arranged for HIV care, nephrology, mood, and chronic pain.

problem_list.problem: Right femoral hemodialysis catheter infection with hypotension
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Presented with pain, swelling, and purulent drainage around the right femoral tunneled dialysis catheter and post‑dialysis hypotension; the catheter was removed, she received empiric cefepime then a 7‑day course of vancomycin dosed with dialysis, and blood cultures remained negative. Ultrasound of the right thigh showed soft tissue edema and a small amount of subcutaneous fluid but no drainable abscess. She never developed fever or bacteremia, the right thigh site healed with no fluctuance or drainage, and her blood pressure stabilized in the 90–100 systolic range without further fluid or pressors. At discharge the infection was clinically resolved and she was off IV antibiotics.

problem_list.problem: End‑stage renal disease on hemodialysis with difficult vascular access
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has HIV‑associated ESRD on chronic hemodialysis. Her infected right femoral catheter was removed, and an initial attempt at left femoral tunneled catheter placement failed due to inability to advance the catheter. A subsequent IR procedure under general anesthesia successfully placed a left femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter with the tip in the right atrium, though advancement past the left iliac vein and IVC was technically difficult. She resumed thrice‑weekly hemodialysis via this catheter, with pre‑dialysis creatinine up to 10 mg/dL and BUN 70 mg/dL improving to creatinine 4–6.5 mg/dL and BUN in the 13–40 mg/dL range, and potassium controlled from a peak of 5.8 mEq/L down to the 3.9–5.2 range. At discharge the left femoral catheter was functioning well and she was scheduled to continue outpatient dialysis.

During left femoral tunneled catheter placement, contrast injection suggested a possible partial thrombus in the IVC, leading to initiation of IV heparin with markedly prolonged PTT values. A subsequent CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast demonstrated a patent IVC with the central venous catheter in place and no filling defect consistent with thrombus. Heparin was discontinued after about 24 hours, and repeat coagulation studies normalized. At discharge there was no evidence of IVC thrombosis and she was not on systemic anticoagulation.

problem_list.problem: HIV/AIDS off HAART with opportunistic infection prophylaxis
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has advanced AIDS with a CD4 count of 41 and a history of multiple PCP episodes and zoster. She was not on HAART at admission due to prior intolerance and non‑adherence, and this was not restarted in hospital per prior outpatient discussions. She remained clinically stable from an HIV standpoint and continued Pneumocystis prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim three times weekly after dialysis and MAC prophylaxis with weekly azithromycin. She was discharged still off HAART, with instructions to follow up with her HIV provider and continue prophylactic regimens.

problem_list.problem: Pancytopenia and anemia of chronic kidney disease
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Throughout the admission she had macrocytic anemia (hemoglobin generally 9–11 g/dL, MCV ~101–106 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.4–3.3 K/uL), and thrombocytopenia (platelets 90–139 K/uL). Coagulation parameters (INR and PT) remained normal. No acute bleeding occurred and no transfusions were required. The cytopenias were attributed to HIV‑related bone marrow suppression and anemia of CKD, and she was discharged with stable counts and plans for outpatient follow‑up.

problem_list.problem: Cardiac rhythm abnormalities and non‑ischemic troponin elevation
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She had a history of atrial fibrillation during prior sepsis episodes. During this admission, an EKG at dialysis showed premature atrial beats in a bigeminal pattern with a rate around 80 and no symptoms; repeat EKG on the floor no longer showed bigeminy. Troponin T was mildly elevated (0.36 ng/mL) with normal CK and CK‑MB and no ischemic EKG changes, interpreted as a stress troponin leak in the setting of hypotension and ESRD rather than acute MI. Given a low CHADS2 score and adherence concerns, warfarin was not started; instead, aspirin was increased from 81 mg to 325 mg daily. She remained hemodynamically stable without chest pain at discharge.

problem_list.problem: Oral candidiasis and chronic throat pain
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She reported several weeks of throat pain on admission. Given her AIDS and exam findings, ENT was consulted and she was treated empirically with nystatin oral suspension for 5–6 days for presumed oral candidiasis. By the end of the hospital stay she reported improvement in throat pain. No obstructing lesions were found, and she was discharged without ongoing antifungal therapy.

She had longstanding depression and postherpetic neuralgia from prior zoster in the right scalp and V1 distribution, with chronic facial rash and right eye involvement. Psychiatry evaluated her and, given lack of active suicidal ideation and prior intolerance to amitriptyline, recommended no new inpatient antidepressant but possible low‑dose mirtazapine and social work follow‑up as an outpatient. Neuralgia and other pain were managed with oxycodone, acetaminophen, and gabapentin every 48 hours, plus hydroxyzine for pruritus. At discharge she remained depressed but without acute safety concerns and had outpatient follow‑up arranged.

key_tests_and_results.result: Portable AP chest radiograph early in the admission showed clear lungs without focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax, normal heart size, and a stable unusual mediastinal contour attributed to collateral vessels from known central venous stenosis, with no acute intrathoracic process.

key_tests_and_results.test: Right thigh ultrasound at prior catheter site
key_tests_and_results.result: Targeted ultrasound of the right proximal thigh at the previous dialysis catheter site demonstrated extensive soft tissue edema and a small amount of subcutaneous fluid (14 x 5 mm) but no organized or drainable abscess; the common femoral artery and vein were patent with appropriate waveforms.

key_tests_and_results.test: Laboratory evaluation of cytopenias and kidney function
key_tests_and_results.result: Serial CBCs showed macrocytic anemia (hemoglobin ~9–11 g/dL, MCV ~101–106 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.4–3.3 K/uL), and thrombocytopenia (nadir platelets ~92–103 K/uL) with normal INR and PT. Chemistry panels reflected ESRD with creatinine ranging from 10 mg/dL pre‑dialysis down to 3.2–6.6 mg/dL post‑dialysis, BUN from 70 mg/dL down to 13–42 mg/dL, and potassium controlled from a peak of 5.8 mEq/L to 3.9–5.2 mEq/L.

Troponin T was mildly elevated at 0.36 ng/mL with normal CK (91 IU/L) and CK‑MB (3 ng/mL), and no ischemic EKG changes were documented, consistent with a non‑ischemic, stress‑related troponin elevation in the setting of hypotension and ESRD rather than acute myocardial infarction.

key_tests_and_results.test: Coagulation studies during and after heparin therapy
key_tests_and_results.result: While on IV heparin for suspected IVC thrombus, PTT was markedly prolonged to 72.9–84.0 seconds with normal INR and PT; after CT ruled out thrombus and heparin was discontinued, PTT normalized to 29.1–31.5 seconds with INR ~0.9 and PT ~9.5–10 seconds.

key_tests_and_results.test: CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast (CT venogram)
key_tests_and_results.result: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with and without IV contrast showed a patent IVC containing the central venous catheter with no filling defect to suggest thrombus, innumerable bilateral renal cysts, two small splenic lesions most consistent with hemangiomas, no retroperitoneal or pelvic lymphadenopathy, and patent pelvic veins.
Blood cultures drawn on admission and the following day showed no growth, indicating that despite the purulent femoral catheter infection, there was no documented bacteremia.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Empiric and targeted IV antibiotics for suspected catheter‑related infection
treatments_and_meds.details: On presentation with a purulent right femoral hemodialysis catheter tunnel infection and hypotension, she received empiric IV cefepime and vancomycin. Cefepime was discontinued early due to low suspicion for gram‑negative infection, while vancomycin was continued as an empiric course dosed with hemodialysis for approximately 7 days after line removal. Vancomycin dosing was guided by serial levels, which were generally in the therapeutic range (around 18–23 ug/mL). She remained afebrile with negative blood cultures throughout.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Removal of infected right femoral catheter and placement of new left femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter
treatments_and_meds.details: The infected right femoral tunneled hemodialysis catheter, which had purulent drainage and tunnel tenderness, was removed prior to or at the time of admission. An initial attempt at left common femoral tunneled catheter placement under local anesthesia was unsuccessful due to inability to advance the catheter, and it was removed. A subsequent procedure under general anesthesia successfully placed a 15.5‑French, 50‑cm tunneled hemodialysis catheter via the left common femoral vein with the tip in the right atrium, though advancement past the left iliac vein and IVC was extremely difficult. The catheter functioned well with good aspiration and flushing and was used for ongoing hemodialysis.

She continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis in hospital via the new left femoral tunneled catheter once placed, with sessions used to control volume status, hyperkalemia (peak K 5.8 mEq/L), and azotemia (creatinine up to 10 mg/dL, BUN 70 mg/dL). Dialysis orders included sodium citrate catheter locks, IV doxercalciferol, and vancomycin dosing per HD protocol. Chronic ESRD medications included cinacalcet 60 mg daily, sevelamer carbonate with meals and snacks (dose reduced due to low phosphorus), folic acid, and Nephrocaps. Post‑dialysis labs showed improved creatinine and BUN and normalized potassium.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Short‑term anticoagulation for suspected IVC thrombus
treatments_and_meds.details: Because contrast injection during left femoral tunneled catheter placement suggested a possible partial IVC thrombus, she was started on IV heparin (bolus and infusion) with PTT‑guided dosing. Coagulation studies showed markedly prolonged PTT while on therapy. After CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast demonstrated a patent IVC without thrombus, heparin was discontinued after roughly 24 hours, and PTT normalized. No long‑term anticoagulation was prescribed at discharge.

Given her advanced AIDS and low CD4 count, she was maintained on Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim DS one tablet three times weekly after hemodialysis and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. These regimens were continued throughout the hospitalization and at discharge, while full HAART was deferred to outpatient management due to prior intolerance and non‑adherence.

For several weeks of throat pain and suspected oral candidiasis, she received nystatin oral suspension 500,000 units swish and swallow three times daily for approximately 5–6 days. ENT evaluation supported this empiric therapy, and she reported symptomatic improvement by the end of the course.

Her chronic postherpetic neuralgia and acute procedural and line‑site pain were managed with oxycodone immediate‑release (2.5–5 mg PO q6h PRN), acetaminophen 500–1000 mg PO q6h PRN, and intermittent IV hydromorphone during procedures. Gabapentin 300 mg PO every 48 hours was used for neuropathic pain. Hydroxyzine 25 mg PO TID PRN was given for pruritus and anxiety. Bowel regimen included docusate sodium and senna to prevent opioid‑induced constipation. These symptomatic treatments were continued or adjusted at discharge as appropriate.

Psychiatry evaluated her for longstanding and acute depression. She denied active suicidal or homicidal ideation. Given prior intolerance to amitriptyline and her current medical complexity, no new antidepressant was started in hospital. Psychiatry recommended outpatient follow‑up with social work and consideration of low‑dose mirtazapine as an outpatient. Discharge planning included referral to outpatient social work and reinforcement of mental health follow‑up.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Antiplatelet therapy for atrial fibrillation risk
treatments_and_meds.details: In light of prior episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response during sepsis and a new episode of bigeminy during dialysis, cardiology and the primary team reviewed her stroke risk. With a low CHADS2 score and concerns about adherence and bleeding risk, warfarin was not initiated. Instead, her aspirin dose was increased from 81 mg to 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis.

disposition.discharge_location: Home with visiting nurse/home health services
